The Rosenthal Effect, also known as the Pygmalion Effect, describes a psychological phenomenon where higher expectations from others lead to an increase in performance. <[silence]> This effect was first identified by psychologist Robert Rosenthal through a series of experiments in educational settings. <[silence]> In these studies, teachers were told that certain students were expected to perform better based on fictitious test results. <[silence]> As a result, those students often showed significant academic improvement, illustrating the power of expectation in influencing behavior. <[silence]>

The mechanism behind the Rosenthal Effect involves subtle, often unconscious, changes in the behavior of those who hold the expectations. <[silence]> For instance, teachers may provide more attention, encouragement, and support to students they believe have higher potential. <[silence]> This additional support can foster a more conducive learning environment, enabling students to achieve better outcomes. <[silence]> The effect is not limited to educational settings and can be observed in various domains, including workplace environments and social interactions. <[silence]>

Critics of the Rosenthal Effect point out the ethical implications of manipulating expectations and the potential for bias. <[silence]> It raises concerns about fairness and the impact of false beliefs on individuals' self-esteem and motivation. <[silence]> Despite these concerns, the phenomenon underscores the significant role that expectations can play in shaping human behavior and performance. <[silence]> Understanding this effect encourages a more mindful approach to setting expectations and interacting with others. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are the Placebo Effect, the Halo Effect, and Self-Determination Theory.
